params.text:
Human activities contribute many toxic metals to the environment:

  1. Burning fossil fuels by driving cars and heating our homes releases chromium, zinc, cadmium and lead into the air.
  2. Then, there's the issue of all the trash:
    • Electronic waste can leach lead, mercury, and cadmium into the soil and water.
    • Landfills can leach many toxic metals into the soil and water.
    • Waste incineration (burning) can release lead and mercury into the air.

hotspots.header: Urban and domestic sources of toxic metals

params.text: The removal of metals in wastewater is done by filtration and other treatment processes (we'll learn more about this later!). While treatment technologies have improved, some toxic metals remain in wastewater that runs directly into our rivers and streams.

Industry is a leading source of toxic metals in the environment. For example,

  1. Metal smelting and refining can release nickel, cadmnium, lead, copper, zinc, mercury, and chromium into the air.
  2. Industrial waste water can directly pollute rivers and streams with toxic metals, and leach into surrounding soil and groundwater.
  3. The chemical industry can directly pollute air and water with toxic metals.
  4. The combustion of fossil fuels for electricity can release cadmium, nickel, mercury, and vanadium into the air and soil.

Geogenic means 'relating to geological processes'. In other words, it's natural! Rocks naturally contain a mixture of metals, including toxic metals. When they are eroded through weathering or blasted into the air in a volcanic eruption, the metals in these rocks find a new home in water, soil, and air.

Mining is considered a major source of toxic metal pollution in the envrionment. Because mining literally digs and grinds up rocks that were once buried and undisturbed, it comes as no surprise that toxic metals in those rocks are released into the air, soil, and water around a mining site.

 

Common toxic metals that are released into the environment from mining practices include arsenic, mercury, lead, zinc, chromium, cadmium, and nickel.

Agricultural (farming) practices release toxic metals into the environment in several ways:

  1. Burning fossil fuels releases chromium, zinc, cadmium, and lead into the air

  2. Commercial inorganic fertilizers can leach chromium, cadmium, copper, zinc, nickel, mangaenese, and lead into the soil and water.

  3. Pesticides can contain copper, zinc, cadmnium, lead, and arsenic, releasing these metals into the air, soil, and water.

  4. Manure and other livestock-related organic waste can release zinc, copper, nickel, lead, cadmnium, chromium, arsenic, and mercury into the soil and water.
Volatilization refers to a chemical process in which a solid (in this case, a toxic metal) dissolves in water and eventually evaporates along with the water into the water vapor in the air.

You might have heard that certain types of seafood are high in mercury and should only be eaten in moderation. This is just one example of how toxic metals in the environment can accumulate (build up) in the tissues of the animals we eat!

Toxic metals get stored in sediments at the bottom of rivers, lakes, and oceans. As these sediments get stirred up, some of those metals can dissolve in water, leading to chemical transformations, volatilization, or uptake by animals and plants. This is just one of the ways that heavy metals are stored and released naturally in the environment. When anthropogenic (human-made) activities dump extra toxic metals into the environment, these cycles are thrown out of balance.

backgroundImageAltText: Toxic heavy metals get into the environment in miriad ways, from natural sources like rock erosion and volcanic activity, to anthropogenic (human-made) sources such as fossil fuel combustion, agriculture, mining, and industrial waste.
